<s> this legal system has several layers more possibly than in most other countries and is due in part to the division between federal and state law <\s>
<s> the united states was founded not as one nation but as a union of 13 colonies each claiming independence from the british crown <\s>
<s> the us constitution implemented in 1789 began shifting power away from the states and toward the federal government though the states today retain substantial legal authority <\s>
<s> us law draws its authority from four sources constitutional law statutory law administrative regulations and case law <\s>
<s> constitutional law is based on the us constitution and serves as the supreme federal law <\s>
<s> taken together with those of the state constitutions these documents outline the general structure of the federal and state governments and provide the rules and limits of power <\s>
<s> us statutory law is legislation enacted by the us congress and is codified in the united states code <\s>
<s> the 50 state legislatures have similar authority to enact state statutes <\s>
<s> administrative law is the authority delegated to federal and state executive agencies <\s>
<s> case law also referred to as common law covers areas where constitutional or statutory law is lacking <\s>
<s> case law is a collection of judicial decisions customs and general principles that began in england centuries ago that were adopted in america at the time of the revolution and that continue to develop today <\s>
<s> legislative branch this entry contains information on the structure unicameral bicameral tricameral formal name number of seats and term of office <\s>
<s> elections includes the nature of the election process or accession to power date of the last election and date of the next election <\s>
<s> election results includes the percent of vote and or number of seats held by each party in the last election <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth this entry contains the average number of years to be lived by a group of people born in the same year if mortality at each age remains constant in the future <\s>
<s> the entry includes total population as well as the male and female components <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth is also a measure of overall quality of life in a country and summarizes the mortality at all ages <\s>
<s> it can also be thought of as indicating the potential return on investment in human capital and is necessary for the calculation of various actuarial measures <\s>
<s> literacy this entry includes a definition of literacy and census bureau percentages for the total population males and females <\s>
<s> there are no universal definitions and standards of literacy <\s>
<s> unless otherwise specified all rates are based on the most common definition the ability to read and write at a specified age <\s>
<s> detailing the standards that individual countries use to assess the ability to read and write is beyond the scope of the factbook <\s>
<s> information on literacy while not a perfect measure of educational results is probably the most easily available and valid for international comparisons <\s>
<s> low levels of literacy and education in general can impede the economic development of a country in the current rapidly changing technology-driven world <\s>
<s> location this entry identifies the country's regional location neighboring countries and adjacent bodies of water <\s>
<s> m major infectious diseases this entry lists major infectious diseases likely to be encountered in countries where the risk of such diseases is assessed to be very high as compared to the united states <\s>
<s> these infectious diseases represent risks to us government personnel traveling to the specified country for a period of less than three years <\s>
<s> the degree of risk is assessed by considering the foreign nature of these infectious diseases their severity and the probability of being affected by the diseases present <\s>
<s> the diseases listed do not necessarily represent the total disease burden experienced by the local population <\s>
<s> the risk to an individual traveler varies considerably by the specific location visit duration type of activities type of accommodations time of year and other factors <\s>
<s> consultation with a travel medicine physician is needed to evaluate individual risk and recommend appropriate preventive measures such as vaccines <\s>
<s> similar to federal states the eu legal system ensures compliance from the member states because of the union's decentralized political nature <\s>
<s> the european court of justice ecj established in 1952 by the treaty of paris has been largely responsible for the development of eu law <\s>
<s> fundamental principles of european union law include subsidiarity the notion that issues be handled by the smallest lowest or least centralized competent authority proportionality the eu may only act to the extent needed to achieve its objectives conferral the eu is a union of member states and all its authorities are voluntarily granted by its members legal certainty requires that legal rules be clear and precise and precautionary principle a moral and political principle stating that if an action or policy might cause severe or irreversible harm to the public or to the environment in the absence of a scientific consensus that harm would not ensue the burden of proof falls on those who would advocate taking the action <\s>
<s> french law a type of civil law that is the legal system of france <\s>
<s> the french system also serves as the basis for or is mixed with other legal systems in approximately 50 countries notably in north africa the near east and the french territories and dependencies <\s>
<s> french law is primarily codified or systematic written civil law <\s>
<s> prior to the french revolution 1789-1799 france had no single national legal system <\s>
<s> laws in the northern areas of present-day france were mostly local customs based on privileges and exemptions granted by kings and feudal lords while in the southern areas roman law predominated <\s>
<s> the introduction of the napoleonic civil code during the reign of napoleon i in the first decade of the 19th century brought major reforms to the french legal system many of which remain part of france's current legal structure though all have been extensively amended or redrafted to address a modern nation <\s>
<s> french law distinguishes between public law and private law <\s>
<s> public law relates to government the french constitution public administration and criminal law <\s>
<s> private law covers issues between private citizens or corporations <\s>
<s> the most recent changes to the french legal system introduced in the 1980s were the decentralization laws which transferred authority from centrally appointed government representatives to locally elected representatives of the people <\s>
<s> international law the law of the international community or the body of customary rules and treaty rules accepted as legally binding by states in their relations with each other <\s>
<s> international law differs from other legal systems in that it primarily concerns sovereign political entities <\s>
<s> there are three separate disciplines of international law public international law which governs the relationship between provinces and international entities and includes treaty law law of the sea international criminal law and international humanitarian law private international law which addresses legal jurisdiction and supranational law a legal framework wherein countries are bound by regional agreements in which the laws of the member countries are held inapplicable when in conflict with supranational laws <\s>
<s> at present the european union is the only entity under a supranational legal system <\s>
<s> the term international law was coined by jeremy bentham in 1780 in his principles of morals and legislation though laws governing relations between states have been recognized from very early times many centuries b c <\s>
<s> modern international law developed alongside the emergence and growth of the european nation-states beginning in the early 16th century <\s>
<s> other factors that influenced the development of international law included the revival of legal studies the growth of international trade and the practice of exchanging emissaries and establishing legations <\s>
<s> the sources of international law are set out in article 38-1 of the statute of the international court of justice within the un charter <\s>
<s> islamic law the most widespread type of religious law it is the legal system enforced in over 30 countries particularly in the near east but also in central and south asia africa and indonesia <\s>
<s> in many countries islamic law operates in tandem with a civil law system <\s>
<s> islamic law is embodied in the sharia an arabic word meaning the right path <\s>
<s> sharia covers all aspects of public and private life and organizes them into five categories obligatory recommended permitted disliked and forbidden <\s>
<s> the primary sources of sharia law are the qur'an believed by muslims to be the word of god revealed to the prophet muhammad by the angel gabriel and the sunnah the teachings of the prophet and his works <\s>
<s> in addition to these two primary sources traditional sunni muslims recognize the consensus of muhammad's companions and islamic jurists on certain issues called ijmas and various forms of reasoning including analogy by legal scholars referred to as qiyas <\s>
<s> shia muslims reject ijmas and qiyas as sources of sharia law <\s>
<s> mixed law also referred to as pluralistic law mixed law consists of elements of some or all of the other main types of legal systems civil common customary and religious <\s>
<s> the mixed legal systems of a number of countries came about when colonial powers overlaid their own legal systems upon colonized regions but retained elements of the colonies existing legal systems <\s>
<s> napoleonic civil code a type of civil law referred to as the civil code or code civil des francais forms part of the legal system of france and underpins the legal systems of bolivia egypt lebanon poland and the us state of louisiana <\s>
<s> the civil code was established under napoleon i enacted in 1804 and officially designated the code napoleon in 1807 <\s>
<s> this legal system combined the teutonic civil law tradition of the northern provinces of france with the roman law tradition of the southern and eastern regions of the country <\s>
<s> the civil code bears similarities in its arrangement to the roman body of civil law see civil law above <\s>
<s> as enacted in 1804 the code addressed personal status property and the acquisition of property <\s>
<s> codes added over the following six years included civil procedures commercial law criminal law and procedures and a penal code <\s>
<s> religious law a legal system which stems from the sacred texts of religious traditions and in most cases professes to cover all aspects of life as a seamless part of devotional obligations to a transcendent imminent or deep philosophical reality <\s>
<s> implied as the basis of religious law is the concept of unalterability because the word of god cannot be amended or legislated against by judges or governments <\s>
<s> however a detailed legal system generally requires human elaboration <\s>
<s> the main types of religious law are sharia in islam halakha in judaism and canon law in some christian groups <\s>
<s> sharia is the most widespread religious legal system see islamic law and is the sole system of law for countries including iran the maldives and saudi arabia <\s>
<s> no country is fully governed by halakha but jewish people may decide to settle disputes through jewish courts and be bound by their rulings <\s>
<s> canon law is not a divine law as such because it is not found in revelation <\s>
<s> it is viewed instead as human law inspired by the word of god and applying the demands of that revelation to the actual situation of the church <\s>
<s> canon law regulates the internal ordering of the roman catholic church the eastern orthodox church and the anglican communion <\s>
<s> roman law a type of civil law developed in ancient rome and practiced from the time of the city's founding traditionally 753 b c until the fall of the western empire in the 5th century a d <\s>
<s> roman law remained the legal system of the byzantine eastern empire until the fall of constantinople in 1453 <\s>
<s> preserved fragments of the first legal text known as the law of the twelve tables dating from the 5th century b c contained specific provisions designed to change the prevailing customary law <\s>
<s> early roman law was drawn from custom and statutes later during the time of the empire emperors asserted their authority as the ultimate source of law <\s>
<s> the basis for roman laws was the idea that the exact form not the intention of words or of actions produced legal consequences <\s>
<s> it was only in the late 6th century a d <\s>
<s> that a comprehensive roman code of laws was published see civil law above <\s>
<s> roman law served as the basis of law systems developed in a number of continental european countries <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law a type of civil law based on roman law as applied in the netherlands <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law serves as the basis for legal systems in seven african countries as well as guyana indonesia and sri lanka <\s>
<s> this law system which originated in the province of holland and expanded throughout the netherlands to be replaced by the french civil code in 1809 was instituted in a number of sub-saharan african countries during the dutch colonial period <\s>
<s> the dutch jurist philosopher hugo grotius was the first to attempt to reduce roman-dutch civil law into a system in his jurisprudence of holland written 1619-20 commentary published 1621 <\s>
<s> the dutch historian lawyer simon van leeuwen coined the term roman-dutch law in 1652 <\s>
<s> spanish law a type of civil law often referred to as the spanish civil code it is the present legal system of spain and is the basis of legal systems in 12 countries mostly in central and south america but also in southwestern europe northern and western africa and southeastern asia <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code reflects a complex mixture of customary roman napoleonic local and modern codified law <\s>
<s> the laws of the visigoth invaders of spain in the 5th to 7th centuries had the earliest major influence on spanish legal system development <\s>
<s> the christian reconquest of spain in the 11th through 15th centuries witnessed the development of customary law which combined canon religious and roman law <\s>
<s> during several centuries of hapsburg and bourbon rule systematic recompilations of the existing national legal system were attempted but these often conflicted with local and regional customary civil laws <\s>
<s> legal system development for most of the 19th century concentrated on formulating a national civil law system which was finally enacted in 1889 as the spanish civil code <\s>
<s> several sections of the code have been revised the most recent of which are the penal code in 1989 and the judiciary code in 2001 <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code separates public and private law <\s>
<s> public law includes constitutional law administrative law criminal law process law financial and tax law and international public law <\s>
<s> private law includes civil law commercial law labor law and international private law <\s>
<s> united states law a type of common law which is the basis of the legal system of the united states and that of its island possessions in the caribbean and the pacific <\s>
<s> this legal system has several layers more possibly than in most other countries and is due in part to the division between federal and state law <\s>
<s> the united states was founded not as one nation but as a union of 13 colonies each claiming independence from the british crown <\s>
<s> the us constitution implemented in 1789 began shifting power away from the states and toward the federal government though the states today retain substantial legal authority <\s>
<s> us law draws its authority from four sources constitutional law statutory law administrative regulations and case law <\s>
<s> constitutional law is based on the us constitution and serves as the supreme federal law <\s>
<s> taken together with those of the state constitutions these documents outline the general structure of the federal and state governments and provide the rules and limits of power <\s>
<s> us statutory law is legislation enacted by the us congress and is codified in the united states code <\s>
<s> the 50 state legislatures have similar authority to enact state statutes <\s>
<s> administrative law is the authority delegated to federal and state executive agencies <\s>
<s> case law also referred to as common law covers areas where constitutional or statutory law is lacking <\s>
<s> case law is a collection of judicial decisions customs and general principles that began in england centuries ago that were adopted in america at the time of the revolution and that continue to develop today <\s>

<s> elections includes the nature of the election process or accession to power date of the last election and date of the next election <\s>
<s> election results includes the percent of vote and or number of seats held by each party in the last election <\s>

<s> detailing the standards that individual countries use to assess the ability to read and write is beyond the scope of the factbook <\s>
<s> information on literacy while not a perfect measure of educational results is probably the most easily available and valid for international comparisons <\s>
<s> low levels of literacy and education in general can impede the economic development of a country in the current rapidly changing technology-driven world <\s>
<s> location this entry identifies the country's regional location neighboring countries and adjacent bodies of water <\s>

<s> these infectious diseases represent risks to us government personnel traveling to the specified country for a period of less than three years <\s>
<s> the degree of risk is assessed by considering the foreign nature of these infectious diseases their severity and the probability of being affected by the diseases present <\s>
<s> the diseases listed do not necessarily represent the total disease burden experienced by the local population <\s>
<s> the risk to an individual traveler varies considerably by the specific location visit duration type of activities type of accommodations time of year and other factors <\s>
<s> consultation with a travel medicine physician is needed to evaluate individual risk and recommend appropriate preventive measures such as vaccines <\s>
<s> similar to federal states the eu legal system ensures compliance from the member states because of the union's decentralized political nature <\s>
<s> the european court of justice ecj established in 1952 by the treaty of paris has been largely responsible for the development of eu law <\s>
<s> fundamental principles of european union law include subsidiarity the notion that issues be handled by the smallest lowest or least centralized competent authority proportionality the eu may only act to the extent needed to achieve its objectives conferral the eu is a union of member states and all its authorities are voluntarily granted by its members legal certainty requires that legal rules be clear and precise and precautionary principle a moral and political principle stating that if an action or policy might cause severe or irreversible harm to the public or to the environment in the absence of a scientific consensus that harm would not ensue the burden of proof falls on those who would advocate taking the action <\s>
<s> french law a type of civil law that is the legal system of france <\s>
<s> the french system also serves as the basis for or is mixed with other legal systems in approximately 50 countries notably in north africa the near east and the french territories and dependencies <\s>
<s> french law is primarily codified or systematic written civil law <\s>
<s> prior to the french revolution 1789-1799 france had no single national legal system <\s>
<s> laws in the northern areas of present-day france were mostly local customs based on privileges and exemptions granted by kings and feudal lords while in the southern areas roman law predominated <\s>
<s> the introduction of the napoleonic civil code during the reign of napoleon i in the first decade of the 19th century brought major reforms to the french legal system many of which remain part of france's current legal structure though all have been extensively amended or redrafted to address a modern nation <\s>
<s> french law distinguishes between public law and private law <\s>
<s> public law relates to government the french constitution public administration and criminal law <\s>
<s> private law covers issues between private citizens or corporations <\s>
<s> the most recent changes to the french legal system introduced in the 1980s were the decentralization laws which transferred authority from centrally appointed government representatives to locally elected representatives of the people <\s>
<s> international law the law of the international community or the body of customary rules and treaty rules accepted as legally binding by states in their relations with each other <\s>
<s> international law differs from other legal systems in that it primarily concerns sovereign political entities <\s>
<s> there are three separate disciplines of international law public international law which governs the relationship between provinces and international entities and includes treaty law law of the sea international criminal law and international humanitarian law private international law which addresses legal jurisdiction and supranational law a legal framework wherein countries are bound by regional agreements in which the laws of the member countries are held inapplicable when in conflict with supranational laws <\s>
<s> at present the european union is the only entity under a supranational legal system <\s>
<s> the term international law was coined by jeremy bentham in 1780 in his principles of morals and legislation though laws governing relations between states have been recognized from very early times many centuries b c <\s>
<s> modern international law developed alongside the emergence and growth of the european nation-states beginning in the early 16th century <\s>
<s> other factors that influenced the development of international law included the revival of legal studies the growth of international trade and the practice of exchanging emissaries and establishing legations <\s>
<s> the sources of international law are set out in article 38-1 of the statute of the international court of justice within the un charter <\s>
<s> islamic law the most widespread type of religious law it is the legal system enforced in over 30 countries particularly in the near east but also in central and south asia africa and indonesia <\s>
<s> in many countries islamic law operates in tandem with a civil law system <\s>
<s> islamic law is embodied in the sharia an arabic word meaning the right path <\s>
<s> sharia covers all aspects of public and private life and organizes them into five categories obligatory recommended permitted disliked and forbidden <\s>
<s> the primary sources of sharia law are the qur'an believed by muslims to be the word of god revealed to the prophet muhammad by the angel gabriel and the sunnah the teachings of the prophet and his works <\s>
<s> in addition to these two primary sources traditional sunni muslims recognize the consensus of muhammad's companions and islamic jurists on certain issues called ijmas and various forms of reasoning including analogy by legal scholars referred to as qiyas <\s>
<s> shia muslims reject ijmas and qiyas as sources of sharia law <\s>
<s> mixed law also referred to as pluralistic law mixed law consists of elements of some or all of the other main types of legal systems civil common customary and religious <\s>
<s> the mixed legal systems of a number of countries came about when colonial powers overlaid their own legal systems upon colonized regions but retained elements of the colonies existing legal systems <\s>
<s> napoleonic civil code a type of civil law referred to as the civil code or code civil des francais forms part of the legal system of france and underpins the legal systems of bolivia egypt lebanon poland and the us state of louisiana <\s>
<s> the civil code was established under napoleon i enacted in 1804 and officially designated the code napoleon in 1807 <\s>
<s> this legal system combined the teutonic civil law tradition of the northern provinces of france with the roman law tradition of the southern and eastern regions of the country <\s>
<s> the civil code bears similarities in its arrangement to the roman body of civil law see civil law above <\s>
<s> as enacted in 1804 the code addressed personal status property and the acquisition of property <\s>
<s> codes added over the following six years included civil procedures commercial law criminal law and procedures and a penal code <\s>
<s> religious law a legal system which stems from the sacred texts of religious traditions and in most cases professes to cover all aspects of life as a seamless part of devotional obligations to a transcendent imminent or deep philosophical reality <\s>
<s> implied as the basis of religious law is the concept of unalterability because the word of god cannot be amended or legislated against by judges or governments <\s>
<s> however a detailed legal system generally requires human elaboration <\s>
<s> the main types of religious law are sharia in islam halakha in judaism and canon law in some christian groups <\s>
<s> sharia is the most widespread religious legal system see islamic law and is the sole system of law for countries including iran the maldives and saudi arabia <\s>
<s> no country is fully governed by halakha but jewish people may decide to settle disputes through jewish courts and be bound by their rulings <\s>
<s> canon law is not a divine law as such because it is not found in revelation <\s>
<s> it is viewed instead as human law inspired by the word of god and applying the demands of that revelation to the actual situation of the church <\s>
<s> canon law regulates the internal ordering of the roman catholic church the eastern orthodox church and the anglican communion <\s>
<s> roman law a type of civil law developed in ancient rome and practiced from the time of the city's founding traditionally 753 b c until the fall of the western empire in the 5th century a d <\s>
<s> roman law remained the legal system of the byzantine eastern empire until the fall of constantinople in 1453 <\s>
<s> preserved fragments of the first legal text known as the law of the twelve tables dating from the 5th century b c contained specific provisions designed to change the prevailing customary law <\s>
<s> early roman law was drawn from custom and statutes later during the time of the empire emperors asserted their authority as the ultimate source of law <\s>
<s> the basis for roman laws was the idea that the exact form not the intention of words or of actions produced legal consequences <\s>
<s> it was only in the late 6th century a d <\s>
<s> that a comprehensive roman code of laws was published see civil law above <\s>
<s> roman law served as the basis of law systems developed in a number of continental european countries <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law a type of civil law based on roman law as applied in the netherlands <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law serves as the basis for legal systems in seven african countries as well as guyana indonesia and sri lanka <\s>
<s> this law system which originated in the province of holland and expanded throughout the netherlands to be replaced by the french civil code in 1809 was instituted in a number of sub-saharan african countries during the dutch colonial period <\s>
<s> the dutch jurist philosopher hugo grotius was the first to attempt to reduce roman-dutch civil law into a system in his jurisprudence of holland written 1619-20 commentary published 1621 <\s>
<s> the dutch historian lawyer simon van leeuwen coined the term roman-dutch law in 1652 <\s>
<s> spanish law a type of civil law often referred to as the spanish civil code it is the present legal system of spain and is the basis of legal systems in 12 countries mostly in central and south america but also in southwestern europe northern and western africa and southeastern asia <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code reflects a complex mixture of customary roman napoleonic local and modern codified law <\s>
<s> the laws of the visigoth invaders of spain in the 5th to 7th centuries had the earliest major influence on spanish legal system development <\s>
<s> the christian reconquest of spain in the 11th through 15th centuries witnessed the development of customary law which combined canon religious and roman law <\s>
<s> during several centuries of hapsburg and bourbon rule systematic recompilations of the existing national legal system were attempted but these often conflicted with local and regional customary civil laws <\s>
<s> legal system development for most of the 19th century concentrated on formulating a national civil law system which was finally enacted in 1889 as the spanish civil code <\s>
<s> several sections of the code have been revised the most recent of which are the penal code in 1989 and the judiciary code in 2001 <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code separates public and private law <\s>
<s> public law includes constitutional law administrative law criminal law process law financial and tax law and international public law <\s>
<s> private law includes civil law commercial law labor law and international private law <\s>
<s> united states law a type of common law which is the basis of the legal system of the united states and that of its island possessions in the caribbean and the pacific <\s>
<s> this legal system has several layers more possibly than in most other countries and is due in part to the division between federal and state law <\s>
<s> the united states was founded not as one nation but as a union of 13 colonies each claiming independence from the british crown <\s>
<s> the us constitution implemented in 1789 began shifting power away from the states and toward the federal government though the states today retain substantial legal authority <\s>
<s> us law draws its authority from four sources constitutional law statutory law administrative regulations and case law <\s>
<s> constitutional law is based on the us constitution and serves as the supreme federal law <\s>
<s> taken together with those of the state constitutions these documents outline the general structure of the federal and state governments and provide the rules and limits of power <\s>
<s> us statutory law is legislation enacted by the us congress and is codified in the united states code <\s>
<s> the 50 state legislatures have similar authority to enact state statutes <\s>
<s> administrative law is the authority delegated to federal and state executive agencies <\s>
<s> case law also referred to as common law covers areas where constitutional or statutory law is lacking <\s>
<s> case law is a collection of judicial decisions customs and general principles that began in england centuries ago that were adopted in america at the time of the revolution and that continue to develop today <\s>
<s> legislative branch this entry contains information on the structure unicameral bicameral tricameral formal name number of seats and term of office <\s>
<s> elections includes the nature of the election process or accession to power date of the last election and date of the next election <\s>
<s> election results includes the percent of vote and or number of seats held by each party in the last election <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth this entry contains the average number of years to be lived by a group of people born in the same year if mortality at each age remains constant in the future <\s>
<s> the entry includes total population as well as the male and female components <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth is also a measure of overall quality of life in a country and summarizes the mortality at all ages <\s>
<s> it can also be thought of as indicating the potential return on investment in human capital and is necessary for the calculation of various actuarial measures <\s>
<s> literacy this entry includes a definition of literacy and census bureau percentages for the total population males and females <\s>
<s> there are no universal definitions and standards of literacy <\s>
<s> unless otherwise specified all rates are based on the most common definition the ability to read and write at a specified age <\s>
<s> detailing the standards that individual countries use to assess the ability to read and write is beyond the scope of the factbook <\s>
<s> information on literacy while not a perfect measure of educational results is probably the most easily available and valid for international comparisons <\s>
<s> low levels of literacy and education in general can impede the economic development of a country in the current rapidly changing technology-driven world <\s>
<s> location this entry identifies the country's regional location neighboring countries and adjacent bodies of water <\s>
<s> m major infectious diseases this entry lists major infectious diseases likely to be encountered in countries where the risk of such diseases is assessed to be very high as compared to the united states <\s>
<s> these infectious diseases represent risks to us government personnel traveling to the specified country for a period of less than three years <\s>
<s> the degree of risk is assessed by considering the foreign nature of these infectious diseases their severity and the probability of being affected by the diseases present <\s>
<s> the diseases listed do not necessarily represent the total disease burden experienced by the local population <\s>
<s> the risk to an individual traveler varies considerably by the specific location visit duration type of activities type of accommodations time of year and other factors <\s>
<s> consultation with a travel medicine physician is needed to evaluate individual risk and recommend appropriate preventive measures such as vaccines <\s>

<s> the european court of justice ecj established in 1952 by the treaty of paris has been largely responsible for the development of eu law <\s>
<s> fundamental principles of european union law include subsidiarity the notion that issues be handled by the smallest lowest or least centralized competent authority proportionality the eu may only act to the extent needed to achieve its objectives conferral the eu is a union of member states and all its authorities are voluntarily granted by its members legal certainty requires that legal rules be clear and precise and precautionary principle a moral and political principle stating that if an action or policy might cause severe or irreversible harm to the public or to the environment in the absence of a scientific consensus that harm would not ensue the burden of proof falls on those who would advocate taking the action <\s>

<s> there are three separate disciplines of international law public international law which governs the relationship between provinces and international entities and includes treaty law law of the sea international criminal law and international humanitarian law private international law which addresses legal jurisdiction and supranational law a legal framework wherein countries are bound by regional agreements in which the laws of the member countries are held inapplicable when in conflict with supranational laws <\s>
<s> at present the european union is the only entity under a supranational legal system <\s>
<s> the term international law was coined by jeremy bentham in 1780 in his principles of morals and legislation though laws governing relations between states have been recognized from very early times many centuries b c <\s>
<s> modern international law developed alongside the emergence and growth of the european nation-states beginning in the early 16th century <\s>
<s> other factors that influenced the development of international law included the revival of legal studies the growth of international trade and the practice of exchanging emissaries and establishing legations <\s>
<s> the sources of international law are set out in article 38-1 of the statute of the international court of justice within the un charter <\s>
<s> islamic law the most widespread type of religious law it is the legal system enforced in over 30 countries particularly in the near east but also in central and south asia africa and indonesia <\s>
<s> in many countries islamic law operates in tandem with a civil law system <\s>
<s> islamic law is embodied in the sharia an arabic word meaning the right path <\s>
<s> sharia covers all aspects of public and private life and organizes them into five categories obligatory recommended permitted disliked and forbidden <\s>
<s> the primary sources of sharia law are the qur'an believed by muslims to be the word of god revealed to the prophet muhammad by the angel gabriel and the sunnah the teachings of the prophet and his works <\s>
<s> in addition to these two primary sources traditional sunni muslims recognize the consensus of muhammad's companions and islamic jurists on certain issues called ijmas and various forms of reasoning including analogy by legal scholars referred to as qiyas <\s>
<s> shia muslims reject ijmas and qiyas as sources of sharia law <\s>
<s> mixed law also referred to as pluralistic law mixed law consists of elements of some or all of the other main types of legal systems civil common customary and religious <\s>
<s> the mixed legal systems of a number of countries came about when colonial powers overlaid their own legal systems upon colonized regions but retained elements of the colonies existing legal systems <\s>
<s> napoleonic civil code a type of civil law referred to as the civil code or code civil des francais forms part of the legal system of france and underpins the legal systems of bolivia egypt lebanon poland and the us state of louisiana <\s>
<s> the civil code was established under napoleon i enacted in 1804 and officially designated the code napoleon in 1807 <\s>
<s> this legal system combined the teutonic civil law tradition of the northern provinces of france with the roman law tradition of the southern and eastern regions of the country <\s>
<s> the civil code bears similarities in its arrangement to the roman body of civil law see civil law above <\s>
<s> as enacted in 1804 the code addressed personal status property and the acquisition of property <\s>
<s> codes added over the following six years included civil procedures commercial law criminal law and procedures and a penal code <\s>
<s> religious law a legal system which stems from the sacred texts of religious traditions and in most cases professes to cover all aspects of life as a seamless part of devotional obligations to a transcendent imminent or deep philosophical reality <\s>
<s> implied as the basis of religious law is the concept of unalterability because the word of god cannot be amended or legislated against by judges or governments <\s>
<s> however a detailed legal system generally requires human elaboration <\s>
<s> the main types of religious law are sharia in islam halakha in judaism and canon law in some christian groups <\s>
<s> sharia is the most widespread religious legal system see islamic law and is the sole system of law for countries including iran the maldives and saudi arabia <\s>
<s> no country is fully governed by halakha but jewish people may decide to settle disputes through jewish courts and be bound by their rulings <\s>
<s> canon law is not a divine law as such because it is not found in revelation <\s>
<s> it is viewed instead as human law inspired by the word of god and applying the demands of that revelation to the actual situation of the church <\s>
<s> canon law regulates the internal ordering of the roman catholic church the eastern orthodox church and the anglican communion <\s>
<s> roman law a type of civil law developed in ancient rome and practiced from the time of the city's founding traditionally 753 b c until the fall of the western empire in the 5th century a d <\s>
<s> roman law remained the legal system of the byzantine eastern empire until the fall of constantinople in 1453 <\s>
<s> preserved fragments of the first legal text known as the law of the twelve tables dating from the 5th century b c contained specific provisions designed to change the prevailing customary law <\s>
<s> early roman law was drawn from custom and statutes later during the time of the empire emperors asserted their authority as the ultimate source of law <\s>
<s> the basis for roman laws was the idea that the exact form not the intention of words or of actions produced legal consequences <\s>
<s> it was only in the late 6th century a d <\s>
<s> that a comprehensive roman code of laws was published see civil law above <\s>
<s> roman law served as the basis of law systems developed in a number of continental european countries <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law a type of civil law based on roman law as applied in the netherlands <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law serves as the basis for legal systems in seven african countries as well as guyana indonesia and sri lanka <\s>
<s> this law system which originated in the province of holland and expanded throughout the netherlands to be replaced by the french civil code in 1809 was instituted in a number of sub-saharan african countries during the dutch colonial period <\s>
<s> the dutch jurist philosopher hugo grotius was the first to attempt to reduce roman-dutch civil law into a system in his jurisprudence of holland written 1619-20 commentary published 1621 <\s>
<s> the dutch historian lawyer simon van leeuwen coined the term roman-dutch law in 1652 <\s>
<s> spanish law a type of civil law often referred to as the spanish civil code it is the present legal system of spain and is the basis of legal systems in 12 countries mostly in central and south america but also in southwestern europe northern and western africa and southeastern asia <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code reflects a complex mixture of customary roman napoleonic local and modern codified law <\s>
<s> the laws of the visigoth invaders of spain in the 5th to 7th centuries had the earliest major influence on spanish legal system development <\s>
<s> the christian reconquest of spain in the 11th through 15th centuries witnessed the development of customary law which combined canon religious and roman law <\s>
<s> during several centuries of hapsburg and bourbon rule systematic recompilations of the existing national legal system were attempted but these often conflicted with local and regional customary civil laws <\s>
<s> legal system development for most of the 19th century concentrated on formulating a national civil law system which was finally enacted in 1889 as the spanish civil code <\s>
<s> several sections of the code have been revised the most recent of which are the penal code in 1989 and the judiciary code in 2001 <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code separates public and private law <\s>
<s> public law includes constitutional law administrative law criminal law process law financial and tax law and international public law <\s>
<s> private law includes civil law commercial law labor law and international private law <\s>
<s> united states law a type of common law which is the basis of the legal system of the united states and that of its island possessions in the caribbean and the pacific <\s>
<s> this legal system has several layers more possibly than in most other countries and is due in part to the division between federal and state law <\s>
<s> the united states was founded not as one nation but as a union of 13 colonies each claiming independence from the british crown <\s>
<s> the us constitution implemented in 1789 began shifting power away from the states and toward the federal government though the states today retain substantial legal authority <\s>
<s> us law draws its authority from four sources constitutional law statutory law administrative regulations and case law <\s>
<s> constitutional law is based on the us constitution and serves as the supreme federal law <\s>
<s> taken together with those of the state constitutions these documents outline the general structure of the federal and state governments and provide the rules and limits of power <\s>
<s> us statutory law is legislation enacted by the us congress and is codified in the united states code <\s>
<s> the 50 state legislatures have similar authority to enact state statutes <\s>
<s> administrative law is the authority delegated to federal and state executive agencies <\s>
<s> case law also referred to as common law covers areas where constitutional or statutory law is lacking <\s>
<s> case law is a collection of judicial decisions customs and general principles that began in england centuries ago that were adopted in america at the time of the revolution and that continue to develop today <\s>
<s> legislative branch this entry contains information on the structure unicameral bicameral tricameral formal name number of seats and term of office <\s>
<s> elections includes the nature of the election process or accession to power date of the last election and date of the next election <\s>
<s> election results includes the percent of vote and or number of seats held by each party in the last election <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth this entry contains the average number of years to be lived by a group of people born in the same year if mortality at each age remains constant in the future <\s>
<s> the entry includes total population as well as the male and female components <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth is also a measure of overall quality of life in a country and summarizes the mortality at all ages <\s>
<s> it can also be thought of as indicating the potential return on investment in human capital and is necessary for the calculation of various actuarial measures <\s>
<s> literacy this entry includes a definition of literacy and census bureau percentages for the total population males and females <\s>
<s> there are no universal definitions and standards of literacy <\s>
<s> unless otherwise specified all rates are based on the most common definition the ability to read and write at a specified age <\s>
<s> detailing the standards that individual countries use to assess the ability to read and write is beyond the scope of the factbook <\s>
<s> information on literacy while not a perfect measure of educational results is probably the most easily available and valid for international comparisons <\s>
<s> low levels of literacy and education in general can impede the economic development of a country in the current rapidly changing technology-driven world <\s>
<s> location this entry identifies the country's regional location neighboring countries and adjacent bodies of water <\s>
<s> m major infectious diseases this entry lists major infectious diseases likely to be encountered in countries where the risk of such diseases is assessed to be very high as compared to the united states <\s>
<s> these infectious diseases represent risks to us government personnel traveling to the specified country for a period of less than three years <\s>
<s> the degree of risk is assessed by considering the foreign nature of these infectious diseases their severity and the probability of being affected by the diseases present <\s>
<s> the diseases listed do not necessarily represent the total disease burden experienced by the local population <\s>
<s> the risk to an individual traveler varies considerably by the specific location visit duration type of activities type of accommodations time of year and other factors <\s>
<s> consultation with a travel medicine physician is needed to evaluate individual risk and recommend appropriate preventive measures such as vaccines <\s>
<s> similar to federal states the eu legal system ensures compliance from the member states because of the union's decentralized political nature <\s>
<s> the european court of justice ecj established in 1952 by the treaty of paris has been largely responsible for the development of eu law <\s>
<s> fundamental principles of european union law include subsidiarity the notion that issues be handled by the smallest lowest or least centralized competent authority proportionality the eu may only act to the extent needed to achieve its objectives conferral the eu is a union of member states and all its authorities are voluntarily granted by its members legal certainty requires that legal rules be clear and precise and precautionary principle a moral and political principle stating that if an action or policy might cause severe or irreversible harm to the public or to the environment in the absence of a scientific consensus that harm would not ensue the burden of proof falls on those who would advocate taking the action <\s>
<s> french law a type of civil law that is the legal system of france <\s>
<s> the french system also serves as the basis for or is mixed with other legal systems in approximately 50 countries notably in north africa the near east and the french territories and dependencies <\s>
<s> french law is primarily codified or systematic written civil law <\s>
<s> prior to the french revolution 1789-1799 france had no single national legal system <\s>
<s> laws in the northern areas of present-day france were mostly local customs based on privileges and exemptions granted by kings and feudal lords while in the southern areas roman law predominated <\s>
<s> the introduction of the napoleonic civil code during the reign of napoleon i in the first decade of the 19th century brought major reforms to the french legal system many of which remain part of france's current legal structure though all have been extensively amended or redrafted to address a modern nation <\s>
<s> french law distinguishes between public law and private law <\s>
<s> public law relates to government the french constitution public administration and criminal law <\s>
<s> private law covers issues between private citizens or corporations <\s>
<s> the most recent changes to the french legal system introduced in the 1980s were the decentralization laws which transferred authority from centrally appointed government representatives to locally elected representatives of the people <\s>
<s> international law the law of the international community or the body of customary rules and treaty rules accepted as legally binding by states in their relations with each other <\s>
<s> international law differs from other legal systems in that it primarily concerns sovereign political entities <\s>
<s> there are three separate disciplines of international law public international law which governs the relationship between provinces and international entities and includes treaty law law of the sea international criminal law and international humanitarian law private international law which addresses legal jurisdiction and supranational law a legal framework wherein countries are bound by regional agreements in which the laws of the member countries are held inapplicable when in conflict with supranational laws <\s>
<s> at present the european union is the only entity under a supranational legal system <\s>
<s> the term international law was coined by jeremy bentham in 1780 in his principles of morals and legislation though laws governing relations between states have been recognized from very early times many centuries b c <\s>
<s> modern international law developed alongside the emergence and growth of the european nation-states beginning in the early 16th century <\s>
<s> other factors that influenced the development of international law included the revival of legal studies the growth of international trade and the practice of exchanging emissaries and establishing legations <\s>
<s> the sources of international law are set out in article 38-1 of the statute of the international court of justice within the un charter <\s>

<s> shia muslims reject ijmas and qiyas as sources of sharia law <\s>

<s> as enacted in 1804 the code addressed personal status property and the acquisition of property <\s>
<s> codes added over the following six years included civil procedures commercial law criminal law and procedures and a penal code <\s>
<s> religious law a legal system which stems from the sacred texts of religious traditions and in most cases professes to cover all aspects of life as a seamless part of devotional obligations to a transcendent imminent or deep philosophical reality <\s>
<s> implied as the basis of religious law is the concept of unalterability because the word of god cannot be amended or legislated against by judges or governments <\s>
<s> however a detailed legal system generally requires human elaboration <\s>
<s> the main types of religious law are sharia in islam halakha in judaism and canon law in some christian groups <\s>
<s> sharia is the most widespread religious legal system see islamic law and is the sole system of law for countries including iran the maldives and saudi arabia <\s>
<s> no country is fully governed by halakha but jewish people may decide to settle disputes through jewish courts and be bound by their rulings <\s>
<s> canon law is not a divine law as such because it is not found in revelation <\s>
<s> it is viewed instead as human law inspired by the word of god and applying the demands of that revelation to the actual situation of the church <\s>
<s> canon law regulates the internal ordering of the roman catholic church the eastern orthodox church and the anglican communion <\s>
<s> roman law a type of civil law developed in ancient rome and practiced from the time of the city's founding traditionally 753 b c until the fall of the western empire in the 5th century a d <\s>
<s> roman law remained the legal system of the byzantine eastern empire until the fall of constantinople in 1453 <\s>
<s> preserved fragments of the first legal text known as the law of the twelve tables dating from the 5th century b c contained specific provisions designed to change the prevailing customary law <\s>
<s> early roman law was drawn from custom and statutes later during the time of the empire emperors asserted their authority as the ultimate source of law <\s>
<s> the basis for roman laws was the idea that the exact form not the intention of words or of actions produced legal consequences <\s>
<s> it was only in the late 6th century a d <\s>
<s> that a comprehensive roman code of laws was published see civil law above <\s>
<s> roman law served as the basis of law systems developed in a number of continental european countries <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law a type of civil law based on roman law as applied in the netherlands <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law serves as the basis for legal systems in seven african countries as well as guyana indonesia and sri lanka <\s>
<s> this law system which originated in the province of holland and expanded throughout the netherlands to be replaced by the french civil code in 1809 was instituted in a number of sub-saharan african countries during the dutch colonial period <\s>
<s> the dutch jurist philosopher hugo grotius was the first to attempt to reduce roman-dutch civil law into a system in his jurisprudence of holland written 1619-20 commentary published 1621 <\s>
<s> the dutch historian lawyer simon van leeuwen coined the term roman-dutch law in 1652 <\s>
<s> spanish law a type of civil law often referred to as the spanish civil code it is the present legal system of spain and is the basis of legal systems in 12 countries mostly in central and south america but also in southwestern europe northern and western africa and southeastern asia <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code reflects a complex mixture of customary roman napoleonic local and modern codified law <\s>
<s> the laws of the visigoth invaders of spain in the 5th to 7th centuries had the earliest major influence on spanish legal system development <\s>
<s> the christian reconquest of spain in the 11th through 15th centuries witnessed the development of customary law which combined canon religious and roman law <\s>
<s> during several centuries of hapsburg and bourbon rule systematic recompilations of the existing national legal system were attempted but these often conflicted with local and regional customary civil laws <\s>
<s> legal system development for most of the 19th century concentrated on formulating a national civil law system which was finally enacted in 1889 as the spanish civil code <\s>
<s> several sections of the code have been revised the most recent of which are the penal code in 1989 and the judiciary code in 2001 <\s>
<s> the spanish civil code separates public and private law <\s>
<s> public law includes constitutional law administrative law criminal law process law financial and tax law and international public law <\s>
<s> private law includes civil law commercial law labor law and international private law <\s>
<s> united states law a type of common law which is the basis of the legal system of the united states and that of its island possessions in the caribbean and the pacific <\s>
<s> this legal system has several layers more possibly than in most other countries and is due in part to the division between federal and state law <\s>
<s> the united states was founded not as one nation but as a union of 13 colonies each claiming independence from the british crown <\s>
<s> the us constitution implemented in 1789 began shifting power away from the states and toward the federal government though the states today retain substantial legal authority <\s>
<s> us law draws its authority from four sources constitutional law statutory law administrative regulations and case law <\s>
<s> constitutional law is based on the us constitution and serves as the supreme federal law <\s>
<s> taken together with those of the state constitutions these documents outline the general structure of the federal and state governments and provide the rules and limits of power <\s>
<s> us statutory law is legislation enacted by the us congress and is codified in the united states code <\s>
<s> the 50 state legislatures have similar authority to enact state statutes <\s>
<s> administrative law is the authority delegated to federal and state executive agencies <\s>
<s> case law also referred to as common law covers areas where constitutional or statutory law is lacking <\s>
<s> case law is a collection of judicial decisions customs and general principles that began in england centuries ago that were adopted in america at the time of the revolution and that continue to develop today <\s>
<s> legislative branch this entry contains information on the structure unicameral bicameral tricameral formal name number of seats and term of office <\s>
<s> elections includes the nature of the election process or accession to power date of the last election and date of the next election <\s>
<s> election results includes the percent of vote and or number of seats held by each party in the last election <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth this entry contains the average number of years to be lived by a group of people born in the same year if mortality at each age remains constant in the future <\s>
<s> the entry includes total population as well as the male and female components <\s>
<s> life expectancy at birth is also a measure of overall quality of life in a country and summarizes the mortality at all ages <\s>
<s> it can also be thought of as indicating the potential return on investment in human capital and is necessary for the calculation of various actuarial measures <\s>
<s> literacy this entry includes a definition of literacy and census bureau percentages for the total population males and females <\s>
<s> there are no universal definitions and standards of literacy <\s>
<s> unless otherwise specified all rates are based on the most common definition the ability to read and write at a specified age <\s>
<s> detailing the standards that individual countries use to assess the ability to read and write is beyond the scope of the factbook <\s>
<s> information on literacy while not a perfect measure of educational results is probably the most easily available and valid for international comparisons <\s>
<s> low levels of literacy and education in general can impede the economic development of a country in the current rapidly changing technology-driven world <\s>
<s> location this entry identifies the country's regional location neighboring countries and adjacent bodies of water <\s>
<s> m major infectious diseases this entry lists major infectious diseases likely to be encountered in countries where the risk of such diseases is assessed to be very high as compared to the united states <\s>
<s> these infectious diseases represent risks to us government personnel traveling to the specified country for a period of less than three years <\s>
<s> the degree of risk is assessed by considering the foreign nature of these infectious diseases their severity and the probability of being affected by the diseases present <\s>
<s> the diseases listed do not necessarily represent the total disease burden experienced by the local population <\s>
<s> the risk to an individual traveler varies considerably by the specific location visit duration type of activities type of accommodations time of year and other factors <\s>
<s> consultation with a travel medicine physician is needed to evaluate individual risk and recommend appropriate preventive measures such as vaccines <\s>
<s> similar to federal states the eu legal system ensures compliance from the member states because of the union's decentralized political nature <\s>
<s> the european court of justice ecj established in 1952 by the treaty of paris has been largely responsible for the development of eu law <\s>
<s> fundamental principles of european union law include subsidiarity the notion that issues be handled by the smallest lowest or least centralized competent authority proportionality the eu may only act to the extent needed to achieve its objectives conferral the eu is a union of member states and all its authorities are voluntarily granted by its members legal certainty requires that legal rules be clear and precise and precautionary principle a moral and political principle stating that if an action or policy might cause severe or irreversible harm to the public or to the environment in the absence of a scientific consensus that harm would not ensue the burden of proof falls on those who would advocate taking the action <\s>
<s> french law a type of civil law that is the legal system of france <\s>
<s> the french system also serves as the basis for or is mixed with other legal systems in approximately 50 countries notably in north africa the near east and the french territories and dependencies <\s>
<s> french law is primarily codified or systematic written civil law <\s>
<s> prior to the french revolution 1789-1799 france had no single national legal system <\s>
<s> laws in the northern areas of present-day france were mostly local customs based on privileges and exemptions granted by kings and feudal lords while in the southern areas roman law predominated <\s>
<s> the introduction of the napoleonic civil code during the reign of napoleon i in the first decade of the 19th century brought major reforms to the french legal system many of which remain part of france's current legal structure though all have been extensively amended or redrafted to address a modern nation <\s>
<s> french law distinguishes between public law and private law <\s>
<s> public law relates to government the french constitution public administration and criminal law <\s>
<s> private law covers issues between private citizens or corporations <\s>
<s> the most recent changes to the french legal system introduced in the 1980s were the decentralization laws which transferred authority from centrally appointed government representatives to locally elected representatives of the people <\s>
<s> international law the law of the international community or the body of customary rules and treaty rules accepted as legally binding by states in their relations with each other <\s>
<s> international law differs from other legal systems in that it primarily concerns sovereign political entities <\s>
<s> there are three separate disciplines of international law public international law which governs the relationship between provinces and international entities and includes treaty law law of the sea international criminal law and international humanitarian law private international law which addresses legal jurisdiction and supranational law a legal framework wherein countries are bound by regional agreements in which the laws of the member countries are held inapplicable when in conflict with supranational laws <\s>
<s> at present the european union is the only entity under a supranational legal system <\s>
<s> the term international law was coined by jeremy bentham in 1780 in his principles of morals and legislation though laws governing relations between states have been recognized from very early times many centuries b c <\s>
<s> modern international law developed alongside the emergence and growth of the european nation-states beginning in the early 16th century <\s>
<s> other factors that influenced the development of international law included the revival of legal studies the growth of international trade and the practice of exchanging emissaries and establishing legations <\s>
<s> the sources of international law are set out in article 38-1 of the statute of the international court of justice within the un charter <\s>
<s> islamic law the most widespread type of religious law it is the legal system enforced in over 30 countries particularly in the near east but also in central and south asia africa and indonesia <\s>
<s> in many countries islamic law operates in tandem with a civil law system <\s>
<s> islamic law is embodied in the sharia an arabic word meaning the right path <\s>
<s> sharia covers all aspects of public and private life and organizes them into five categories obligatory recommended permitted disliked and forbidden <\s>
<s> the primary sources of sharia law are the qur'an believed by muslims to be the word of god revealed to the prophet muhammad by the angel gabriel and the sunnah the teachings of the prophet and his works <\s>
<s> in addition to these two primary sources traditional sunni muslims recognize the consensus of muhammad's companions and islamic jurists on certain issues called ijmas and various forms of reasoning including analogy by legal scholars referred to as qiyas <\s>
<s> shia muslims reject ijmas and qiyas as sources of sharia law <\s>
<s> mixed law also referred to as pluralistic law mixed law consists of elements of some or all of the other main types of legal systems civil common customary and religious <\s>
<s> the mixed legal systems of a number of countries came about when colonial powers overlaid their own legal systems upon colonized regions but retained elements of the colonies existing legal systems <\s>
<s> napoleonic civil code a type of civil law referred to as the civil code or code civil des francais forms part of the legal system of france and underpins the legal systems of bolivia egypt lebanon poland and the us state of louisiana <\s>
<s> the civil code was established under napoleon i enacted in 1804 and officially designated the code napoleon in 1807 <\s>
<s> this legal system combined the teutonic civil law tradition of the northern provinces of france with the roman law tradition of the southern and eastern regions of the country <\s>
<s> the civil code bears similarities in its arrangement to the roman body of civil law see civil law above <\s>
<s> as enacted in 1804 the code addressed personal status property and the acquisition of property <\s>
<s> codes added over the following six years included civil procedures commercial law criminal law and procedures and a penal code <\s>
<s> religious law a legal system which stems from the sacred texts of religious traditions and in most cases professes to cover all aspects of life as a seamless part of devotional obligations to a transcendent imminent or deep philosophical reality <\s>
<s> implied as the basis of religious law is the concept of unalterability because the word of god cannot be amended or legislated against by judges or governments <\s>
<s> however a detailed legal system generally requires human elaboration <\s>
<s> the main types of religious law are sharia in islam halakha in judaism and canon law in some christian groups <\s>
<s> sharia is the most widespread religious legal system see islamic law and is the sole system of law for countries including iran the maldives and saudi arabia <\s>
<s> no country is fully governed by halakha but jewish people may decide to settle disputes through jewish courts and be bound by their rulings <\s>
<s> canon law is not a divine law as such because it is not found in revelation <\s>
<s> it is viewed instead as human law inspired by the word of god and applying the demands of that revelation to the actual situation of the church <\s>
<s> canon law regulates the internal ordering of the roman catholic church the eastern orthodox church and the anglican communion <\s>
<s> roman law a type of civil law developed in ancient rome and practiced from the time of the city's founding traditionally 753 b c until the fall of the western empire in the 5th century a d <\s>
<s> roman law remained the legal system of the byzantine eastern empire until the fall of constantinople in 1453 <\s>
<s> preserved fragments of the first legal text known as the law of the twelve tables dating from the 5th century b c contained specific provisions designed to change the prevailing customary law <\s>
<s> early roman law was drawn from custom and statutes later during the time of the empire emperors asserted their authority as the ultimate source of law <\s>
<s> the basis for roman laws was the idea that the exact form not the intention of words or of actions produced legal consequences <\s>
<s> it was only in the late 6th century a d <\s>
<s> that a comprehensive roman code of laws was published see civil law above <\s>
<s> roman law served as the basis of law systems developed in a number of continental european countries <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law a type of civil law based on roman law as applied in the netherlands <\s>
<s> roman-dutch law serves as the basis for legal systems in seven african countries as well as guyana indonesia and sri lanka <\s>
<s> this law system which originated in the province of holland and expanded throughout the netherlands to be replaced by the french civil code in 1809 was instituted in a number of sub-saharan african countries during the dutch colonial period <\s>
<s> the dutch jurist philosopher hugo grotius was the first to attempt to reduce roman-dutch civil law into a system in his jurisprudence of holland written 1619-20 commentary published 1621 <\s>
<s> the dutch historian lawyer simon van leeuwen coined the term roman-dutch law in 1652 <\s>
